Award.AbstractNarration:
Social identity, or perceived memberships in relevant social groups, can influence a wide range of processes, including how we perceive, evaluate, and interact with others. The proposed research examines the role of group membership on person perception, theorizing that it will be easier to perceive in-group members as having their own thoughts, goals and feelings relative to members of other groups. This is important, as the ability to infer states in others can facilitate social interactions, appropriate responding to others' emotions, and the perception that others have moral rights and responsibilities. Conversely, when people do not perceive others as having their own thoughts, goals and feelings, they may be more likely to respond with prejudice and discrimination. Therefore, this work has the potential to provide new ways of understanding how group identity influences perceptual processes, suggest novel techniques to reduce real world prejudice and discrimination, and to improve cooperation between members of different groups.

Jay Van Bavel (New York University) will conduct a series of studies to examine how perceptions of others are influenced by individuals' group identity (e.g., team membership, national identity). The research team will examine this question in relation to: [1] the importance people place on their group memberships and whether people believe that their group is threatened by an out-group; [2] the neural systems that underlie this relationship; [3] how biases against an out-group affect behavior (e.g., aggression, intergroup conflict, and care); and [4] methods to reduce bias against out-groups. By examining these factors, this proposed research will result in new theorizing about the role of social identity on perceptions of others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mind perception, the understanding that other people have their own thoughts, goals, and feeling, is an essential part of human social interaction. In addition to facilitating people’s detection of other social agents in their environment, mind perception is thought to underlie empathy and perspective-taking and allows people to see other individuals as worthy of moral consideration. Failures of mind perception can facilitate prejudice and inhumane acts such as torture. Recent research suggests that mind perception, on the other hand, is an automatic response to certain physical features (e.g., eyes). Our work has found the identity also plays a key role in how we determine the mental capacities of others.

Specifically, our research has identified why people more readily perceive a mind in members of their in-group, but not members of out-groups. Specifically, people who care deeply about their groups are more susceptible to this pattern of bias and is may help explain why people mistreat other groups and deny them access to pain medicine and other care. Our research adds to a growing understanding of mind perception by examining the issue across different types of groups (e.g., group membership, political affiliation, national identity) and different measures of prejudice and discrimination. This research offers potential benefits to society in both obtaining a better understanding of why people get dehumanized by others and providing the means to reduce real world prejudice and discrimination against and foster cooperation with out-group members.

 To examine how mind perception is shaped by the social identity, we conducted a series of behavioral and neuroimaging studies. Participants in these studies examined a series of morphs between human and non-human (e.g., doll) faces that varied in the influence of the human and non-human faces described as in-group or out-group members. In general, in-group members required less humanness in a face than out-group members to be perceived as having minds. This work has helped us establish the foundation for a new framework for understanding mind perception and has informed subsequent work on group differences in empathy, intergroup dynamics, and prejudice.

Thanks, in part, to this grant, the PI has published over 40 additional papers and chapters, successfully mentored numerous students, and presented related research at numerous conferences and colloquia. The PI also received early career awards from the Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Association for Psychological Science, and American Psychological Foundation. Lab members supported by this have published numerous papers, won professional awards, and accepted postdoc (Stanford) or faculty positions  (Rutgers, Delaware) and RAs have gone on to excellent Ph.D. programs as well as medical and professional schools. Trainees participated in all phases of research and we emphasized opportunities for students who were diverse with respect to race, gender, nationality, and sexual orientation. NSF funding helped us these activities and enriched interdisciplinary training in social neuroscience at NYU by expanding courses, training, workshops, and related activities.

This funded also fostered the broad dissemination of scientific understanding. Our lab produced numerous scientific papers (publicly available on our website and preprint servers) as well as accessible accounts of research to the public. In addition to publishing in peer-reviewed journals, work from our lab was covered in major media outlets and disseminated to the public through radio and print interviews, social media (e.g., twitter), public lectures, op-eds, and science websites. Further, the PI recently cofounded a mentoring column for Science Magazine called “Letters to Young Scientists” to share career advice with scientists around the world and across numerous disciplines.
